by Ethan Rarick
The Student Council and the
Student Activities Commission
General Assembly both
unanimously passed a 1984-85
SAC budget of $121,360 on
Wednesday.
The budget provides for a
Contingency Fund of $12,343.
During the year, SAC groups
may request additional money
from that fund.
The total budget represents
roughly a 7 percent increase
over last year, when the total
was $113,420.

originally drawn up by the SAC
Executive Board, must be approved by both the SAC
General Assembly and the Student Council to become final.

attempt to cut funding for the
Band to $6250.

the Chess Club. Bogstad
pointed out that the Band was
receiving MOO for lodging for
two away lacrosse games. He
said the Band is the only SAC.
organization which receives
funding for lodging for out-oftown trips, and that his club

been refused similar funding.

not receive money for lodging

voted down, however, 28-11-7.

play at all lacrosse games.

budgeted for away lacrosse

at the University require that
the band be present at all

Crackdown on Fake Degrees
Campus Digest News Service

Realizing that selling
counterfeit diplomas is a large
business with thousands of
"graduates," the Federal
Bureau of Investigation is
cracking down on "diploma
mill" officials.
The fraudulent "colleges"
bring in millions of dollars, says
Special Agent Allen Ezell of the
bureau's Charlotte, N.C., office. Diploma mills being investigated vary in price and ser-

vices offered; one convicted official allegedly charged $700 for
a diploma, another, $500, and
still others as much as $2,700
for combined master's and doctoral degrees. The cheapest
diploma Ezell has seen was
$39.95.
Two types of fake diplomas
are offered: counterfeit
diplomas from real colleges and
degrees from nonexistent institutions, Ezell said.
The FBI has received complaints from every state in the

U.S., and its investigation
began nearly four years ago in
South Carolina with a man who
had issued 620 diplomas.
Two grand jury indictments
have been made recently in
operation "Dipscam", and as
many as 40 more may be made
in the near future. The first
two, John Blazer and Charles
Durham, were indicted in
South Carolina. Blazer has
been sentenced to two years in
prison.

Return of the Landlord
For one of the few times this year, a student appeared before the Student Council to
inform them of a problem.
On March 7, David Briggs, at the request
of the Housing Committee, came to a council meeting to discuss the problems he had
had with the maintenance staff of Universityowned apartments.
He called the Housing Office "unresponsive and insensitive to the needs of student
tenants." He told council members about a
faulty hot-water pipe in his McCoy apartTent that has been a problem since
September and has been "fixed inadequately" a number of times.
He added that the office's maintenance
staff consists of "fix-it-all types," that the
University lacks proper housing management
and takes advantage of its tenants.
It was also at this meeting that the Housing Committee announced that they were
distributing questionnaires to determine
whether other students had similar complaints against the Housing Office/maintenance staff.
About 25% of the 375 undergraduates living in off-campus, University-owned apartments have returned the questionnaire.
While relatively few complaints concerning
minor repairs were reported, the ones concerning major repairs, such as the faulty hotwater pipe in Briggs' apartment, were
numerous.
According to the responses, when a major
problem is initially reported, the maintenance staff seldom gets an outside contractor to make the necessary repairs. Instead,
they try to fix it themselves. They usually
can't, though, for they lack the necessary
expertise that a full-time plumber or electrician possesses. So the problem either goes
unresolved or, in some cases, gets even
worse.
While the goal of the questionnaire was
to determine whether maintenance was a
problem, it also revealed something else.
Housing Office personnel have difficulty

dealing with students. They're not always
cooperative and behave as if their privacy
were being violated when tenants open the
office door to ask a question. They simply
don't know how to relate to people.
The Housing Committee has accomplished
a great deal with the questionnaire, but much
more needs to be done.
There's no reason why the University
maintains its apartments in the manner in
which they are currently being maintained.
There's no reason why Housing Office
personnel can't interact with students.
Perhaps work-study students should replace
them; students usually can get along with
other students.
There's no reason why undergraduates
shouldn't be allowed to pay their rent on a
monthly basis, instead of paying one amount
at the beginning of each semester. The 300
graduate students living in off-campus,
University-owned apartments pay a monthly
rent because most of them rely on fellowship
money, which comes in monthly installments.
Some undergraduates and their families face
similar financial difficulty and would prefer
the monthly arrangement. They should be
given that option.
There's no reason why one individual
shouldn't be taking complaints when
students call the Housing Office. Plant
Operations has such an arrangement.
And finally, there is no reason why the
Housing Office should mail letters to those
students who have already signed leases notifying them that space is still available in
University housing. Not only do they waste
20 cents by sending letters to off-campus addresses instead of dropping them in campus
mail, but they also send several letters to each
student.
That makes sense, doesn't it? If you
entered the lottery four times and have
already signed a lease, you should have
received three letters by now.
No wonder there will be a thousand dollar
tuition increase next year.

What Do You Think of Your Roommate Today?
by Susan Kaplan

"

What would college be like
without roommates? Probably
a lot saner, a lot healthier. College is difficult for the new
student—and for the veteran as
well—and there are enough adjustments to be made without
the added stress of learning to
live in a cell with a stranger.
For one thing, no roommate
would probably mean more
time to study and that, of
course, is the student's goal.
For all the time spent deciding
if the noise level in the other
room was loud enough to really prevent concentration and if
maybe you should go to the
library to study, or if you
should just join the TV watchers, you could probably have
written your senior thesis. The
time involved in helping your
roommate get over a "fun
mood" or talking her through
her writer's block so that she'd
stop distracting you could surely have been spent more con-

structively on your own work.
It would also mean easier access to the bathroom. It can be
trying first thing on a cold morning when you're late for class
to find the bathroom door locked. And when you come back
a few minutes later to find it
still locked because your roommate's boyfriend is taking a!
shower, it can actually put you
in a black mood for the whole
day.
No roommate would mean
not having to find somewhere
else to spend the night when
you come home to find a "do
not disturb" sign on your door.
The first time this happens
freshman year, the usual
response is something like
"Outrageous! Who ever heard
of such a thing?! I live here
too..." etc., as you slink off to
sleep on a friend's floor. The
next time you're less shocked,
but no less angry—that never
goes away.
It would mean a lot less
frustration, tension, and

restrained outbursts (not to
mention unrestrained outbursts) over those little ideosyncracies that make a roommate
hard to live with, those annoying habits that are so ingrained
in her personality that she
doesn't even know they're
there. Like that laugh, and the
way she sneezes when she's nervous. And what about yours?
All those times she told you not
to do something you'd been doing all your life, just because it
bothered
her.
How
unreasonable to ask you—and
in that tone of voice!...to lower
your music, your voice, your
phone bills. And the nerve to
point out that you cough each
time you turn a page and that
it's really annoying and please
not to do it anymore.
What would college be like
without roommates? Maybe a
lot saner, but certainly a lot less
interesting. What would we do
without an automatic friend
during that first terrifying week
of college, without someone to

go to all those parties and
dances with during orientation,
without someone to eat with
those first lonely meals away
from home?
By your fourth year, it
becomes a lot easier to ignore
loud chewing, long showers,
slamming doors in the middle
of the night, and dishes piled so
high you begin to fear an
avalanche. Without a roommate there would be none of

those late-night talks, no one to
bitch about or with, no one to
help you justify that finalsweek eating binge. By the end
of four years of college, there's
probably no one who knows
you as well, and no one with
whom you share so many
memories—good ones as well
as not-so-good ones.
Susan Kaplan is a senior
majoring in international
relations.

In hoops, home is where the
heart is. Proof positive is
Lamar University from Alamo
Country has now won 78 consecutive home games, the
longest home streak going right
now, and sixth longest in the
history of the NCAA.
Lamar recently beat Louisiana Tech, 85-60, for No. 78.
But what makes that so interesting is that Lamar had
been beaten by Tech by 23
points at Ruston, La., back in
January.
Think about it. How in the
world can home advantage account for a 48-point spread in
a two-game series?
Let me show you why it's
almost always Miller Time at
home.
First, you must realize that
officials cannot counter their
subconscience of the crowd, the
cheering of the crowd. They
hear the crowd, and it's only
human that anyone appreciates
a pat on the back, applause,
rather than a kick in the pants.
Second, remember the
ballplayers for the home team
have slept in their own bed the

night before, stayed with their
normal routine, and they are
accustomed to the weather in
that area and the food they eat.
The visitors, on the other hand,
have just endured the nonstructured discipline of making
planes, checking into hotel
rooms, and irregular eating
habits, psychologically, they
are in disarray.
Third, all good basetball
teams know they're supposed
to win at home.
It's a psychological feeling
that's padded by playing in
front of your fraternity
brothers and lady friends,
faculty, parents and the inevitable alumni glad-handers. A
security blanket feeling, really,
like coming home when you
were a kid and seeing the light
on over the back porch.
For the home team, the arena
is like the playground down the
street, or the basket over the
garage in your driveway.
You're familiar with the floor
and have a positive feeling.
Like a lot of times, teams play
on portable courts, and the
visiting team doesn't know
where the soft spots are, where
the ball doesn't bounce un nor-

mally, and the home team will
put defensive pressure on the
ball handler at those spots.
Another example: If the
visiting team likes to fast-break
a lot, the home team might wet
the nets, so the ball won't come
through as fast. That stops their
fast break.
A lot of times, the home
team puts their band or their
football players behind the
visitors' bench, so it's difficult
to concentrate during time outs.
Sometimes, they'll put extra
heat in the locker room to sap
the strength of the players. And
usually, at half time, the key to
the locker room becomes a
phantom and you're stuck in
the hallway four or five
minutes.
So what we're talking about
is playing in a whole friendly
environment versus the
hostilities of the snake pits the
players visit on the road.
That's why good teams hardly ever lose at home. Any team
that's in the top 15 in the country will very rarely lose more
than two games at home in a
season.
For trivia buffs: The longest
home streak ever was by Kentucky, 129 straight from
1943-55. St. Bonnie was second, with 99 from 1948-61, the
Bruins of UCLA third with 98
from 1970-76, then Cincinnati
with 90, from 1957-64.
Arizona, from 1945-51, and my
Marquette teams from 1967-73,
are tied for fifth with 81, a
number Lamar can equal if
they win their last regular
season home game, and the two
games in their conference
tourney.

place in the division. Salzer lost
a close match in the consolation
round.

Baseball was the game of the

cents could get you into Fenway
park to watch a game from the
bleachers on a warm summer

discuss Gibson's jug-handle

phenom pitching in Texas.

But, today, when I pick up a
sports page, I read about a different game of baseball,
Mediocre players insist on
being paid half a million dollars
a year to play the game I always
dreamed of playing, but was
never able.
I read about Juan Bonilla,
the second-rate second
baseman for the San Diego
Padres: "I've used drugs. I've
smoked my joints. I've done
my lines of cocaine. But, tell
me, who hasn't?"
Indeed, who hasn't?

refuse to play without red Converse spies and a $90 mitt
autographed by Bucky Dent.

double-knit uniforms and
mothers with Ford station
wagons to drive them up to the
steps of the dugout or they
won't play. Today, kids prefer
video games.

Route Two now sponsors a slopitch softball team and the
rocky field where Eric Sinn performed his magic is now oc-

stadiums and astroturf; 24
cameras covering the World
Series; lawyers and agents;
owners and board room
meetings; salaries and arbitration; strikes. Money.
I look at my mitt, the pocket
held together by a shoe string,
and think about baseball-past.
I tell myself that all things
change and some of the changes
in baseball are for the best.

that I haven't lost an old friend.

What Do You Think of Your Roommate Today?
by Susan Kaplan

"

What would college be like
without roommates? Probably
a lot saner, a lot healthier. College is difficult for the new
student—and for the veteran as
well—and there are enough adjustments to be made without
the added stress of learning to
live in a cell with a stranger.
For one thing, no roommate
would probably mean more
time to study and that, of
course, is the student's goal.
For all the time spent deciding
if the noise level in the other
room was loud enough to really prevent concentration and if
maybe you should go to the
library to study, or if you
should just join the TV watchers, you could probably have
written your senior thesis. The
time involved in helping your
roommate get over a "fun
mood" or talking her through
her writer's block so that she'd
stop distracting you could surely have been spent more con-

structively on your own work.
It would also mean easier access to the bathroom. It can be
trying first thing on a cold morning when you're late for class
to find the bathroom door locked. And when you come back
a few minutes later to find it
still locked because your roommate's boyfriend is taking a!
shower, it can actually put you
in a black mood for the whole
day.
No roommate would mean
not having to find somewhere
else to spend the night when
you come home to find a "do
not disturb" sign on your door.
The first time this happens
freshman year, the usual
response is something like
"Outrageous! Who ever heard
of such a thing?! I live here
too..." etc., as you slink off to
sleep on a friend's floor. The
next time you're less shocked,
but no less angry—that never
goes away.
It would mean a lot less
frustration, tension, and

restrained outbursts (not to
mention unrestrained outbursts) over those little ideosyncracies that make a roommate
hard to live with, those annoying habits that are so ingrained
in her personality that she
doesn't even know they're
there. Like that laugh, and the
way she sneezes when she's nervous. And what about yours?
All those times she told you not
to do something you'd been doing all your life, just because it
bothered
her.
How
unreasonable to ask you—and
in that tone of voice!...to lower
your music, your voice, your
phone bills. And the nerve to
point out that you cough each
time you turn a page and that
it's really annoying and please
not to do it anymore.
What would college be like
without roommates? Maybe a
lot saner, but certainly a lot less
interesting. What would we do
without an automatic friend
during that first terrifying week
of college, without someone to

go to all those parties and
dances with during orientation,
without someone to eat with
those first lonely meals away
from home?
By your fourth year, it
becomes a lot easier to ignore
loud chewing, long showers,
slamming doors in the middle
of the night, and dishes piled so
high you begin to fear an
avalanche. Without a roommate there would be none of

those late-night talks, no one to
bitch about or with, no one to
help you justify that finalsweek eating binge. By the end
of four years of college, there's
probably no one who knows
you as well, and no one with
whom you share so many
memories—good ones as well
as not-so-good ones.
Susan Kaplan is a senior
majoring in international
relations.

subconscience of the crowd, the
cheering of the crowd. They
hear the crowd, and it's only
human that anyone appreciates
a pat on the back, applause,
rather than a kick in the pants.
Second, remember the
ballplayers for the home team
have slept in their own bed the

night before, stayed with their
normal routine, and they are
accustomed to the weather in
that area and the food they eat.
The visitors, on the other hand,
have just endured the nonstructured discipline of making
planes, checking into hotel
rooms, and irregular eating
habits, psychologically, they
are in disarray.
Third, all good basetball
teams know they're supposed
to win at home.
It's a psychological feeling
that's padded by playing in
front of your fraternity
brothers and lady friends,
faculty, parents and the inevitable alumni glad-handers. A
security blanket feeling, really,
like coming home when you
were a kid and seeing the light
on over the back porch.
For the home team, the arena
is like the playground down the
street, or the basket over the
garage in your driveway.
You're familiar with the floor
and have a positive feeling.
Like a lot of times, teams play
on portable courts, and the
visiting team doesn't know
where the soft spots are, where
the ball doesn't bounce un nor-

mally, and the home team will
put defensive pressure on the
ball handler at those spots.
Another example: If the
visiting team likes to fast-break
a lot, the home team might wet
the nets, so the ball won't come
through as fast. That stops their
fast break.
A lot of times, the home
team puts their band or their
football players behind the
visitors' bench, so it's difficult
to concentrate during time outs.
Sometimes, they'll put extra
heat in the locker room to sap
the strength of the players. And
usually, at half time, the key to
the locker room becomes a
phantom and you're stuck in
the hallway four or five
minutes.
So what we're talking about
is playing in a whole friendly
environment versus the
hostilities of the snake pits the
players visit on the road.
That's why good teams hardly ever lose at home. Any team
that's in the top 15 in the country will very rarely lose more
than two games at home in a
season.
